facts.text: Five different suits were filed against certain defendants on the foot of five different pronotes.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals have been brought by certificate from a companymon judgment of the Orissa High Court. Five different suits were filed against certain defendants on the foot of five different pronotes.

concepts.interpretation: Creates a complete bar to production of tax documents by public servants and mandates confidentiality, but permits admissibility if produced by the assessee waiving privilege.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: Ghose  2  companysidered it startling that when an assessment order was to be treated as companyfidential under s. 54 of the Act a joint assessee comp

concepts.unlisted_description: Provisions on confidentiality of income-tax returns, statements, records, and prohibition on courts requiring production by public servants except as provided.

anchor.surface_text: Section 54 1  of the Act was in the following terms S. 54 1  All particulars contained in any statement made, return furnished or accounts or documents produced under the provisions of this Act, or in any evidence given, or affidavit or deposition made, in the course of any proceedings under this Act other than proceedings under this Chapter, or in any record of any assessment proceeding, or any proceeding relating to the recovery of a demand, prepared for the purposes of this Act, shall be treated as confidential, and notwithstanding anything contained in the Indian Evidence Act, 1872  1 of 1872 , noCourt shall, save as provided in this Act, be entitled to require any public servant to produce before it any such return, accounts, documents of record or any part of any such record, or to give evidence before it in respect thereof.

concepts.unlisted_description: Provisions on confidentiality of income-tax returns, statements, records, and prohibition on courts requiring production by public servants except as provided.

anchor.surface_text: Now it is quite clear that s. 54 created a complete bar to the production by officials and other servants of the Income tax Department of any such documents which were mentioned in sub-ss.  1  and  2 .

concepts.interpretation: Applies absolute prohibition on tax officials disclosing or producing documents, but not on assessee.

issues.text: whether if a copy of the assessment order or a certified copy thereof was produced by the assessee waiving his privilege it would be admissible in evidence

anchor.surface_text: After examining s. 54 of the Income tax Act 1922 and the various decisions of the High Courts the learned judges of the High Court ,game to the conclusion that the general consensus was that if a copy of the assessment order or a certified copy thereof was produced by the assessee waiving his privilege it would be admissible in evidence.

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary for the purposes of this case to go into the larger question of production of the documents covered by s. 54 1 by third parties as it was the son of Manilal the assessee who had produced the assessment orders which are in dispute. There is an overwhelming weight of authority in favour of the view that assessment orders could be produced by the assessee or his representative-in- interest

arguments.claim: s. 54 created a complete bar to the production by officials and other servants of the Income tax Department of any such documents which were mentioned in sub-ss. (1) and (2).

anchor.surface_text: Now it is quite clear that s. 54 created a complete bar to the production by officials and other servants of the Income tax Department of any such documents which were mentioned in sub-ss. (1) and (2).

arguments.claim: The prohibition imposed under s. 54 of the Act was absolute and the operation of the section was not obliterated by any waiver by the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: There the appellant had applied to the trial court praying that the Commissioner of Income tax be directed to arrange for the production before the court of the record of the statement made by the respondent therein. In that situation it was held that the prohibition imposed under s. 54 of the Act was absolute and the operation of the section was not obliterated by any waiver by the assessee

arguments.claim: Statements made in income tax returns could not be brought up in court against the person making them or against any one else nor could the income returns be proved by secondary evidence under s. 64 of the Indian Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: The question which came up for consideration before the courts was if the documents could be given without requiring a public servant to produce them could the court allow them to be tendered and admitted into evidence ? The Madras High Court held in Mythili Ammal v. Janaki Ammal Another   that statements made in income tax returns could not be brought up in court

arguments.claim: When an assessment order was to be treated as confidential under s. 54 of the Act a joint assessee could not be permitted the use of the copy of such an order to the detriment of his co-assessee in contentious proceedings between them.

anchor.surface_text: against the person making them or against any one else not could the income returns be proved by secondary evidence under s. 64 of the Indian Evidence Act. The Calcutta High Court in Promatha Nath Pramanick v. Nirode Chandra Ghose  2  considered it startling that when an assessment order

arguments.claim: A return was confidential and could not be disclosed to a third party but there could be no objection to the maker of a return having a COPY for his own purposes if he so desired and he was not bound to treat the document as confidential. In other words he could produce that document as evidence in court.

anchor.surface_text: A Full Bench of the Madras High Court, however, held in Rama Rao v. Venkataramayya 3  that a return was confidential and could not be disclosed to a third party but there could be no objection to the maker of a return having a COPY for his own purposes if he so desired

holdings.text: Section 54 of the Income Tax Act, 1922 created a complete bar to the production by officials and other servants of the Income Tax Department of documents mentioned in sub-sections (1) and (2).

anchor.surface_text: Now it is quite clear that s. 54 created a complete bar to the production by officials and other servants of the Income tax Department of any such documents which were mentioned in sub-ss. (1) and (2). It also made it obligatory on them to treat as confidential the records and documents mentioned in the sub-sections.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of s.54(1) and (2), prohibiting courts from requiring public servants to produce or give evidence on confidential tax records.

holdings.text: Assessment orders produced by the assessee or his representative-in-interest are admissible in evidence.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the law laid down by these cases on the admissibility of evidence of assessment orders produced by an assessee or his representative-in-interest is unexceptionable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overwhelming weight of High Court authority (Emperor v. Osman Chotani, Suraj Narain v. Seth Jhabhu Lal, Buchibai v. Nagpur University) supports admissibility upon waiver by assessee; s.54 bars only public officials, not assessee.

holdings.text: The son of the assessee qualifies as representative-in-interest entitled to produce assessment orders, making them admissible.

anchor.surface_text: There is an overwhelming weight of authority in favour of the view that assessment orders could be produced by the assessee or his representative-in- interest see Emperor v. Osman Chotani 4 , Suraj Narain v. Seth Jhabhu Lal Others 5  and Buchibai v. Nagpur University 6 . In our opinion the law laid down by these cases...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show son of Manilal (assessee) produced orders; precedents confirm representative-in-interest can waive and produce.

holdings.text: Charu Chandra Kundu v. Gurupada Ghosh holds that s.54 prohibition is absolute when court directs tax authorities to produce records, even with assessee waiver; inapplicable where assessee produces own records.

anchor.surface_text: the prohibition imposed under s. 54 of the Act was absolute and the operation of the section was not obliterated by any waiver by the assessee... It is apparent that in that case the question of production of an assessment order by the assessee himself did not come up for consideration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes precedent: Charu Chandra involved court compelling Commissioner, not voluntary production by assessee.

holdings.text: The assessment orders are admissible to prove contesting defendants were partners of firm Surajmal Manilal.

anchor.surface_text: the sole question which has been agitated before us relates to the admissibility of certain assessment orders on which reliance has been placed for deciding whether the contesting defendants were the partners of firm Surajmal Manilal... In our opinion the law laid down by these cases on the admissibility of evidence of assessment orders produced by an assessee or his representative-in-interest is unexceptionable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sole issue affirmed by upholding admissibility; lower court findings on partnership via these orders accepted implicitly by dismissing appeals.

These appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts. One hearing fee.

edges.explanation: Holding that assessment orders are admissible to prove partnership directly addresses and resolves the sole question of their admissibility.

anchor.surface_text: the sole question which has been agitated before us relates to the admissibility of certain assessment orders on which reliance has been placed for deciding whether the contesting defendants were the partners of firm Surajmal Manilal... In our opinion the law laid down by these cases on the admissibility of evidence of assessment orders produced by an assessee or his representative-in-interest is unexceptionable.
These appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts. One hearing fee.
